segment.source: How to Remove a Package by Using the Command Line
segment.target: How to Remove a Package by Using the Command Line

segment.source: How to Remove a Package by Using the Command Line
segment.target: How to Remove a Package by Using the Command Line

segment.source: How to Remove a Package by Using the Command Line
segment.target: How to Remove a Package by Using the Command Line

segment.source: You can use the following command-line procedures to delete a virtual application package from the Application Virtualization (App-V) Client on a specific computer.
segment.target: You can use the following command-line procedures to delete a virtual application package from the Application Virtualization (App-V) Client on a specific computer.

segment.source: To delete a virtual application package for all users
segment.target: To delete a virtual application package for all users

segment.source: If the package was previously added for all users by using the /GLOBAL switch, use the following command to delete the package and the global file types and shortcuts.
segment.target: If the package was previously added for all users by using the /GLOBAL switch, use the following command to delete the package and the global file types and shortcuts.

segment.source: Administrator rights are required.
segment.target: Administrator rights are required.

segment.source: The /GLOBAL switch is not needed in this case because the command always performs a global deletion of the package.
segment.target: The /GLOBAL switch is not needed in this case because the command always performs a global deletion of the package.

segment.source: To delete a package previously added for individual users
segment.target: To delete a package previously added for individual users

segment.source: If the package was previously added for individual users, you have several options.
segment.target: If the package was previously added for individual users, you have several options.

segment.source: Run the following command once under the user account of each person the package was published to.
segment.target: Run the following command once under the user account of each person the package was published to.

segment.source: This denies the user access to the applications if they roam to another computer.
segment.target: This denies the user access to the applications if they roam to another computer.

segment.source: It deletes the specific user’s settings, shortcuts, and file types from the profile, and it stops background loads under the user’s context.
segment.target: It deletes the specific user’s settings, shortcuts, and file types from the profile, and it stops background loads under the user’s context.

segment.source: Alternatively, run the following command under the user account of each person the package was published to.
segment.target: Alternatively, run the following command under the user account of each person the package was published to.

segment.source: Then run this command for the package.
segment.target: Then run this command for the package.

segment.source: This completely removes the package, and it deletes all user settings, shortcuts, and file types from their profiles.
segment.target: This completely removes the package, and it deletes all user settings, shortcuts, and file types from their profiles.

segment.source: If the package is subsequently re-added, the users will have to specify their settings again.
segment.target: If the package is subsequently re-added, the users will have to specify their settings again.

segment.source: Only “Delete applications” (DeleteApp) permission is needed to run this command.
segment.target: Only “Delete applications” (DeleteApp) permission is needed to run this command.

segment.source: As a third alternative, you can simply run the DELETE PACKAGE command without using the UNPUBLISH PACKAGE command.
segment.target: As a third alternative, you can simply run the DELETE PACKAGE command without using the UNPUBLISH PACKAGE command.

segment.source: In this case, file types and shortcuts for each user are hidden rather than deleted, and the user settings are retained.
segment.target: In this case, file types and shortcuts for each user are hidden rather than deleted, and the user settings are retained.

segment.source: This means that if the package is subsequently re-added for the user, the file types and shortcuts are restored, and the user settings are reapplied.
segment.target: This means that if the package is subsequently re-added for the user, the file types and shortcuts are restored, and the user settings are reapplied.
